title: Royal Air Force March Past
text:
The "Royal Air Force March Past" is the official <a href="march%20%28music%29">march</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> (RAF) and is used in some other <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> air forces.
The original score was completed by <a href="Walford%20Davies">Walford Davies</a> in 1918 for the new RAF. It combined the rhythm of the <a href="bugle%20call">bugle call</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a> with that of the <a href="Royal%20Naval%20Air%20Service">Royal Naval Air Service</a>. The call appears in both the introduction and the <a href="coda%20%28music%29">coda</a>. It was originally known as the Adastral I (in reference to the <a href="Per%20ardua%20ad%20astra">RAF's motto</a>). The second part of the march past, the <a href="march%20%28music%29%23The%20March%20Music%20Form">trio</a>, was composed by <a href="George%20Dyson%20%28composer%29">Sir George Dyson</a>.
The march can be played both as a slow march and a quick march, and has been used as both when the <a href="Queen%27s%20Colour%20Squadron">Queen's Colour Squadron</a> and RAF bands perform public duties such as mounting the guard at <a href="Buckingham%20Palace">Buckingham Palace</a>.
Canadian version.
Authority was granted in February 1943 by <a href="Office%20of%20Public%20Sector%20Information">His Majesty's Stationery Office</a> to publish the "RAF March Past" piece in Canada under the title "RCAF March Past". It was the official march of the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a> until the unification of the <a href="Canadian%20Forces">Canadian Armed Forces</a> in 1968. It continued to be the authorized march of <a href="Canadian%20Forces%20Air%20Command">Air Command</a> and the <a href="Air%20Operations%20Branch">Air Operations Branch</a> of the Canadian Forces from 1968-2011. In 2011 Air Command reverted its name to <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a> and the RCAF March Past continues as the official march of the RCAF. It is also the official march of the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Cadets">Royal Canadian Air Cadets</a> and the <a href="Air%20Force%20Association%20of%20Canada">Air Force Association of Canada</a>.
A pipe band arrangement was composed in the 1950s by <a href="Pipe%20Major">Pipe Major</a> <a href="Alex%20Howie">Alex Howie</a> of the <a href="CFB%20Trenton">CFB Trenton</a> <a href="Pipe%20Band">Pipe Band</a>, and a trio for pipes was composed in 1970 by Pipe Major <a href="Archie%20Cairns">Archie Cairns</a>.
Lyrics.
The following are the lyrics to be sung to the Trio section of the march (composed by George Dyson). It references the <a href="motto">motto</a> of the RAF, ""<a href="Per%20Ardua%20Ad%20Astra">Per Ardua Ad Astra</a>"" (<a href="Latin%20language">Latin</a>, "Through adversity to the stars").
